prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see here. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for refusing to buy family members Christmas gifts. The situation is that the author won a $400 gift card, told their sister, who then called the author. The sister talked to the mom, who then pressured the author to buy gifts for the sister, mom, and two cousins. The author felt the pressure was too much, especially since the cousins are young and not close, so they decided not to buy anything for family and spent the money on themselves instead. The mom got upset and there was an argument.

First, I need to consider the age of the person. The author is 15, so maybe they're still learning about social norms and family expectations. At that age, financial independence and personal spending choices might be a new concept. They might not have a lot of money, so $400 is a significant amount. 

The mom's reaction is part of the issue here. She seemed to take the gift card and then dictated how it should be spent. The author felt their autonomy was invaded when the mom and sister took the gift card and added more people. The cousins are 6 and 2, so maybe the author doesn't have a close relationship with them, making the purchase feel unnecessary. 

Family expectations can vary. Some families might expect you to share in certain ways, but others might be more individualistic. The author's frustration comes from being pressured to spend money on people they don't see often, especially after the mom's obnoxious comments. 

The key points are the pressure from family to spend money on others versus personal choice. The author might be in the right for asserting their right to spend their own money as they see fit, especially if the family was overstepping. However, the author could also be seen as being selfish or not considering family traditions. 

But considering the mom's behavior—taking the gift card and adding more people without respecting the author's financial boundaries—maybe the author is justified in their decision. The age factor also plays a role; at 15, they might be developing a sense of personal responsibility and boundaries. 

So, is the author in the wrong? Probably not. They are standing up for their autonomy, even if the family didn't like it. The parents might have overstepped, so the author's choice to not comply is reasonable. Answer B.
